FacilityName: San Francisco Refinery at Rodeo, California

for fires, explosions, releases of hazardous materials and medical emergencies. The ERP addresses coordination with local agencies and the public. 

The ERP has been prepared in coordination with the local emergency response area plan (the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan).  In addition, the ERP contains a number of annexes, including the SFR Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan and the Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasures Plan. 

The ERP is an important resource tool that includes sections on the Incident Command System, roles and responsibilities, alarm and notification systems, response procedures for specific emergencies, internal and external resources, training and drill requirements, medical surveillance for emergency responders and ERP review and updating procedures. The ERP also discusses emergency procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases and addresses emergency medical treatment.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The facility is committed to ensuring its operations are safe and in accordance with all RMP requirements. To ensure that appropriate changes are implemented as necessary to maintain and improve safety, ongoing PHAs, training, reviews and updates of operating procedures, audits, maintenance, and investigations will be conducted as required by the RMP. 

The SFR identifies ways to improve safety through a number of avenues, which include PHAs, audits, incident investigations, employee suggestions, and the preventative maintenance program.  Recommended changes are evaluated for implementation to improve the overall safety of the facility. 

In the pursuit of continuous improvement, the refinery seeks and evaluates methods to improve the safety of its operations. 

The Metallurgical Engineering and Inspection (ME&I) Department has well established inspection programs for piping, vessels and tanks that are consistent with American Petroleum Institute (AP

ments. 
¿ The Process Engineering supervisor is responsible for the Process Safety Information (PSI) program element. 
¿ Personnel in the Health and Safety Department have responsibility for Hot Work, Contractors, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, Employee Participation, and Training. 
¿ Training for Operators and Operating Procedures are the responsibility of the Operations Department. 
¿ Training for maintenance employees is the responsibility of the Maintenance Department. 
¿ Mechanical Integrity is jointly owned between Technical Services and Maintenance Departments. 

The SFR's Policies and Procedures Manual contains all the policies pertaining to safety and environmental performance and is available to employees on the SFR's intranet, as well as in hard copy in central locations at the refinery. Senior Management is ultimately responsible for the Policies and Procedures Manual. The manual contains Emergency Response Policies, which establish a management standard for reporting emergencies, response to emergencies, and individual employee actions during emergencies. 

FACILITY OVERVIEW AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Phillips 66 SFR is located in unincorporated Contra Costa County, near the town of Rodeo. The refinery encompasses a total of 1,100 acres of land, consisting of the 495-acre active area of the refinery, where all its facilities and equipment are located, and another 600 acres of undeveloped areas. It is bordered by the NuStar Terminal to the north, and an undeveloped area to the east. To the south is a 300- to 600-foot undeveloped area (property maintained as buffer areas between the active or developed portion of the refinery and adjacent land uses), beyond which is the Bayo Vista residential area. San Pablo Bay borders the refinery to the west.

Interstate Highway 80 and San Pablo Avenue run north-south through the refinery property. The property is zoned as heavy industrial. Land uses to the northe

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Phillips 66 Company (Phillips 66) San Francisco Refinery at Rodeo (SFR or refinery) is located in unincorporated Contra Costa County, near the town of Rodeo, California. The SFR encompasses a total of 1,100 acres of land, consisting of the 495-acre active area of the refinery, where all its facilities and equipment are located, and another 600 acres of undeveloped areas. The SFR consists of refining processes and support units that produce fuels, sulfur, and petroleum coke. The refinery's principal activity is fuels manufacturing, wherein the facility converts crude oil and other feedstock into gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, and industrial fuels. Numerous chemicals, materials, and utilities are required to produce useful products from the crude oil. 

The SFR is subject to RMP requirements because it stores and uses regulated substances in quantities exceeding the regulated thresholds. The refinery contains flammables, hydrogen sulfide (H2S), and aqueous ammonia (NH3) in quantities that exceed their respective RMP thresholds. The purpose of the RMP program is to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and minimize the severity of those releases if they should occur. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The SFR's Commitment to Responsible Business Policy best depicts the mission and vision set forth for the refinery. The Policy emphasizes the commitment to operate and maintain the facility and equipment in a manner that promotes (1) the health, safety, and security of employees, neighbors, and the public and (2) the responsible use of resources and care of the environment. The refinery's mission statement also includes a safe work environment for employees. 
The SFR has a policy advocating a safe workplace and sound environmental operations. Phillips 66 places primary responsibility for health, safety, and the environment within each of the major facilities. Each major facility has comprehensive pro

grams and policies for addressing these areas.  The Health, Environmental and Safety Policy established by the corporation is included in its entirety below:
Phillips 66 is committed to the safety of everyone who works in our facilities, lives in the communities where we operate or uses our products. We will conduct our business with care for the environment. We strive for world class operating excellence by integrating our Health, Occupational Safety, Process Safety and Environmental principles throughout our businesses with a commitment to continuous improvement.

Our Action Plan

¿ Comply with all applicable laws and regulations
¿ Attain incident free operations through systematic risk identification and mitigation
¿ Use resources efficiently and minimize environmental impact
¿ Ensure a safe, healthy and secure work place
¿ Provide our employees and contractors with the knowledge and capability to achieve HSE excellence including empowering them to stop work they believe is unsafe
¿ Set operational and compliance objectives and be accountable for our performance
¿ Communicate our principles and results to employees, contractors, regulators, communities and other stakeholders

The Release Prevention Program Elements are part of the overall safety program at the refinery. The SFR uses a Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) Management System (HSEMS) to coordinate the programs as required by the Phillips 66 corporate standard. The objective of the SFR HSEMS is to ensure that business activities are conducted in a safe and environmentally responsible manner through the implementation of the HSE policies and the Phillips 66 HSEMS Standard. This objective is achieved by providing organizational structure, programs, procedures, processes, and resources to manage the business activities safely and with respect and care for the environment. The HSEMS seeks to:
¿ Demonstrate management commitment to health, safety, and environmental stewardship.
¿ Ensure th

at all reasonably practicable steps are taken to identify the hazards and risks arising from our business activities.
¿ Establish adequate control over business activities with the aim of achieving safe, incident- and injury-free working conditions.
¿ Maximize operational integrity, reliability, and efficiency.
¿ Ensure regulatory compliance.
¿ Promote high standards and the continuous improvement of our HSE performance.

The HSEMS system is described in the SFR HSEMS Program Description document available to all employees via the company intranet (Connect66). The document provides a description of the programs, procedures, and processes that are in place at the SFR to implement the Phillips 66 Company and SFR's HSE policies. The corporate HSEMS Standard describes a five-phase continuous improvement cycle of Policy and Leadership, Plan, Do, Assess, and Adjust built around 15 management system elements.  Each management system element is assigned to an Element Owner, who has the responsibility for its implementation. Senior Management has the overall responsibility for the HSEMS. Many of the elements, such as Asset & Operations Integrity, mirror elements of the RMP. 

The Element Owner conducts an annual evaluation following the HSEMS Excellence Assessment Process model to assess performance levels and identify areas for improvement. Each Element Owner, working with a team of employees, develops annual improvement goals. Goals are based on the HSEMS Standard, the annual review, audit findings, employee suggestions, incident statistics, leading metrics, incident investigations, best practices, and other sources. The HSE Manager and the Refinery Leadership Team develop strategic HSE goals for inclusion in the annual Business Planning process. 

Similarly, the RMP elements are assigned Element Owners as follows: 
¿ The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) coordinator is responsible for PHA, Management of Change (MOC) and Pre Start-Up Safety Review (PSSR) program ele

I) Inspection Codes, CCR Petroleum Safety Orders, and company Inspection Best Practices. 

Improvements in available technology provide another opportunity to enhance facility safety. Inherently Safer Systems are actively studied as a part of all new project implementation work. Improving health, safety, and environmental performance is a top priority at the SFR.

ast of the refinery are a combination of industrial and open space. To the east is primarily open space, and a combination of residential, light commercial, and light industrial uses are found to the south and southwest. The nearest sensitive receptor is a day-care facility in the Bayo Vista residential area, near the southern property boundary, south of the undeveloped buffer zone.
 
The refinery consists of refining processes and support units that produce fuels, sulfur, and petroleum coke. The refinery's principal activity is fuels manufacturing, wherein the facility converts crude oil and other feedstock into gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, and industrial fuels. The principal fuels produced are gasoline, diesel, and jet fuels. The refinery also produces butane, elemental sulfur, and petroleum coke for commercial purposes.

The SFR is designed and operated to refine a variety of domestic and foreign crude oils.  Crude oil is brought to the refinery via pipeline and marine tanker. Tankers dock at the refinery's Marine Terminal, located at the northwestern edge of the facility.

Numerous chemicals, materials, and utilities are required to produce useful products from the crude oil. Some chemicals, such as hydrogen, are produced at the SFR or supplied by Air Liquide, which operates a hydrogen Production Plant adjacent to the refinery. Other feedstock, chemicals, and materials are purchased and transported to the facility. The refinery generates its own steam, fuel gas, and electricity, and purchases other resources, such as natural gas. 

The refinery accomplishes the production of these products from crude oil through the use of many complex processing units.  Crude oil is sent to distillation units to make the first separation of crude oil into its various components. Additional processing takes place in a number of refinery units including coking, isomerization, hydrocracking, reforming, and blending units. The following discussion describes the SFR's existin

g processes.

The SFR has two crude processing units. The Crude Distillation Unit processes light, sweet crude oil from overseas. Processing begins in the Desalter, where the oil is dehydrated and salts are removed electrically to reduce the corrosivity of the oil. Following desalting, it is sent to a distillation tower where the hydrocarbons are heated and separated into fractions by molecular weight. Lighter hydrocarbons have lower boiling points than heavier hydrocarbons. This unit  produces six different fractions: vent gas, light naphtha, medium naphtha, light diesel, heavy diesel, and vacuum resid. The second crude unit is associated with the Coker. It processes diluted San Joaquin Valley Crude into three fractions: naphtha, gas oil, and vacuum resid. The heaviest fraction, resid, is composed of very heavy hydrocarbons and is a solid at ambient temperatures. This material is sent to the Coker, where the large molecules are thermally cracked into smaller ones. These smaller molecules can then be further processed into motor fuels. The Coker also produces petroleum coke, which is shipped offsite.

The gas oil fractions from the crude units and the Coker are still too large for use as motor fuels. These fractions are catalytically cracked in the Unicracker  and the heavy gas oil Hydrocracker Unit. These units crack the hydrocarbon molecules into smaller molecules in the presence of hydrogen and a catalyst. 

Hydrocracking is more selective than thermal cracking. Olefins and other unsaturated compounds are saturated during this hydrocracking process in addition to breaking larger chain or ringed hydrocarbons into smaller compounds. Olefins are undesirable in motor fuels because they contribute to the formation of smog during engine combustion; therefore, they must be removed.

The diesel and naphtha hydrotreating units remove sulfur and nitrogen from their feedstocks, creating hydrogen sulfide and ammonia, which are processed elsewhere. These units also sa

turate olefins. These units are particularly important for ensuring cleaner burning fuels, since the removal of these compounds is critical to preventing smog from engine combustion of gasoline and diesel. The Unisar Unit removes aromatic compounds from its feedstock by saturating these compounds. The Unisar Unit produces finished aviation jet fuel. The reformer units rearrange hydrocarbons from straight chains into branched chains and rings. The Isomerization unit rearranges molecules to raise the octane number of the motor fuels. 

The cracking processes produce very small hydrocarbons as well as the larger fractions discussed above. Units like the Gasoline Fractionation Unit separate these small molecules. The smallest molecules (one, two, and three carbons) are used in the refinery for fuel. Butanes are produced for commercial sale. 

The refinery has a Steam Power Plant that produces electricity as well as high pressure, high temperature steam, which is used for heating various processes. The Steam Power Plant's demineralizer produces high quality water for use in the plant and process cooling systems. The Waste Water Treatment Plant treats water used in refinery processes. The water that is removed from crude oil prior to processing and water from other process stages, including stripped sour water, is treated by biological systems and carbon filtration prior to its permitted discharge. In addition, selenium is removed by the Selenium Removal Plant.

The sulfur and nitrogen removed from processing streams is sent to the Sulfur Complex.  The Sulfur Complex converts the sulfur in the streams (as hydrogen sulfide) into elemental sulfur. The elemental sulfur is sold to agricultural markets.

Description of Regulated Substances
Most of the substances handled at the refinery regulated by the RMP are flammables. These materials range in flammability from pentane (with a flash point greater than -40°F) to hydrogen (with a flash point of -100 °F). A high flash

point indicates less flammability. Materials with low flash points must be handled carefully and isolated from ignition sources to prevent fires or explosions. For comparison, gasoline has a flash point of -45°F and diesel fuel has a flash point of 125°F. 

As part of refining crude oil to motor fuels, some regulated toxic substances are generated in addition to the flammables. Hydrogen sulfide and aqueous ammonia are present at the refinery at quantities exceeding their regulatory limits. Hydrogen sulfide, with its characteristic rotten egg odor, is created in the processing units that remove sulfur and nitrogen from the refining streams. It is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas and its odor can be readily detected at concentrations below concern. Hydrogen sulfide is not stored at the refinery. As soon as it is generated, it is sent to the Sulfur Complex for processing. In addition, minor amounts of hydrogen sulfide may evolve from spills of sour water. Ammonia is also created and treated by the same processing units. Ammonia is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas with a sharp irritating odor. Its odor is also readily detectable at concentrations below concern. The SFR uses aqueous ammonia for nitrogen oxide emission control. Hydrogen sulfide and ammonia are hazardous principally through inhalation. 

There are several other regulated substances present at the refinery at quantities below their regulatory thresholds, and thus not subject to RMP requirements.  No other substances at the refinery are included in the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 40, Part 68.130, Tables 1 and 2. 

The maximum inventories of applicable RMP chemicals stored at the SFR are provided per Title 40 CFR 68.115. Only streams containing one percent or greater of a regulated toxic or flammable material are included in the reported inventories. Toxic mixtures with a partial pressure of the regulated substance below 10 millimeters

of mercury are not included. For toxic mixtures, only the weight of the regulated substance is reported. For flammable mixtures, the entire weight of the mixture is treated as the regulated substance, per Title 40 CFR 68.115 (b)(2). However, flammable mixtures that do not have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of 4 are not covered under RMP.  

Covered Processes
This RMP divides the refinery into twelve processes.  For processes that exceed the maximum intended inventory thresholds for regulated substances, the RMP defines three program levels, each with its own requirements. The applicable program level is dependent upon the complexity, accident history, and potential impact of releases of regulated substances.  The SFR has both Program Level 1 and Program Level 3 processes. The covered processes for the SFR are:

PROGRAM LEVEL 1:
¿ Isomerization Unit 
¿ MP30 Complex
¿ Diesel Hydrotreater

PROGRAM LEVEL 3:
¿ Butane Systems
¿ Steam Power Plant NOx Controls
¿ Coker 
¿ Gasoline Fractionation
¿ Fuel Gas Center
¿ Unicracker
¿ Reforming Unit
¿ Heavy Hydrocracker
¿ Crude Unit

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

The Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act restricts the distribution of offsite consequence analysis (OCA) information for security purposes. For this reason, the OCA for the SFR is not included here. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM/POLICIES AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The RMP for the hazardous substances regulated by federal RMP regulations have been developed and implemented to enhance employee and public safety. 

Management Systems
The SFR has implemented a management system for developing and continually improving the RMP elements. The Health, Safety & Environmental Manager has the overall responsibility for the management of the RMP. The facility has developed a PSM/RMP Compliance Audit program to help ensure compliance with the fe

cess flow valves;
¿ Instrument failure: periodic testing of critical safety devices, including pressure safety valves. 

Many of the safeguards mentioned above are automatic safety systems that are commonly referred to as interlocks. In addition, the refinery has a flare system that will safely burn vented materials from the process units. 

While the emphasis is on prevention of potential hazards, the refinery also implements a number of mitigation measures in the event a release should occur. The SFR recognizes that early detection is an important part of managing a release. An example of a detection safeguard would be that process and storage areas have leak detection systems for hydrocarbons and hydrogen sulfide. In addition, the SFR has perimeter monitors for hydrogen sulfide and sulfur dioxide as well as a fence-line monitoring system. Mitigation is also an important part of managing an accidental release. 

Examples of mitigation safeguards include emergency block valves, depressurizing, equipment spacing, dikes, curbs and sewers, fire-fighting access, hydrants, monitors, deluge systems, proper fireproofing of vessels, proper pipe supports, and critical instrument controls. 

As part of safeguarding against escalation of an event, the refinery has a comprehensive Emergency Response Program.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The RMP regulation requires a listing of accidents for the past 5 years from covered processes that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The SFR has not had an accident involving a covered process that met these criteria in the last 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The emergency response program is described in a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which consists of organization, procedures, and equipment for an emergency response. This program addresses emergency responses
